newsitem.title: UK: Britain calls on Iran to denounce Rushdie bounty.
newsitem.headline: Britain calls on Iran to denounce Rushdie bounty.

text.p: Britain called on Iran on Wednesday to denounce an increased bounty offered for the killing of British writer Salman Rushdie.
But a leading Iranian politician distanced his government from the new offer of a $2.5 million reward and said Tehran's policy on the author of the novel,"The Satanic Verses", had not changed.

Mohammad Javad Larijani, deputy chairman of the Iranian Majlis (parliament) foreign relations committee, said the 15th Khordad (June Fifth) Foundation, which offered the increased reward, was a charitable body that did not represent the government.

"This foundation can say anything they want," Larijani told a London news conference. "The position of the government is as it was before. The government of Iran is not going to despatch any death squads to kill the citizen of another country."
Larijani was speaking as Iran's President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani used a Tehran news conference to say his government had nothing to do with the new reward.

The foundation first offered the bounty in 1989 after Iran's late leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued a fatwa, or religious edict, imposing a "death sentence" on Rushdie for alleged blasphemy against Islam in "The Satanic Verses".
Since then, Rushdie has been under 24-hour police protection, although he has in the past year been increasing the number of public appearances he makes.
Iranian officials say the ruling is a purely religious matter, unrelated to the government. They stress it cannot withdraw a religious edict.
Ayatollah Hassan Sanei, head of the foundation, was quoted by the daily Jomhuri Eslami on Wednesday as saying the charity would raise the award by $500,000.
The British Foreign Office said it had noted Sanei's announcement "with great concern".
"We condemn the bounty as we condemn the fatwa itself as an outrageous infringement of Mr Rushdie's fundamental rights," a statement said.
It said it did not accept that the 15th Khordad Foundation had nothing to do with the Iranian government.
"We call on President Rafsanjani specifically to condemn the bounty," the Foreign Office statement added.
The Guardian newspaper meanwhile said that security surrounding Rushdie had been stepped up following the discovery of fresh plans to carry out the death threat.
